coreCitation.title: Boston Internet Access
coreCitation.briefDescription: Rate of internet subscription as a percent of total households in Census tracts within the City of Boston, five year averages 2014â€“2018
coreCitation.fullNotes: This dataset, which was acquired from data.census.gov, contains statistical information aggregated to the Census tract level and clipped to the extent of the city of Boston. It includes information about the total number of households in Boston per Census tract, the total number of households without an internet subscription in Boston per Census tract, and a normalized field for the percent of households for each Census tract in Boston without internet. This data came from the American Community Survey rolling 5-year estimates, and covers a time period from 2014-2018.
coreCitation.briefGenealogy: This recipe was created from two ingredients: (1) Census tract geometry shapes, and (2) Statistical tables containing the number of total households and internet subscriptions in each Census tract. These two ingredients were combined together using GIS software. The statistical tables were cleaned to include only fields that are noteworthy for this particular subject of study.
importantAttributes: No Internet as Percent of Total Households
coreCitation.accessCondition: This dataset is in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use.

dataEndpoints.title: Internet Access in Boston Statistical Tables

temporal.temporalNotes: This dataset is derived as rolling estimates from the 2014-2018 5-year American Community Survey

representation.healthCheckQualifier: There is strong documentation about the process by which survey questions were initially designed, how stakeholders were involved, and the process by which new questions are added. There could be healthier context made available for continuous efforts to ensure adequate representation in the survey design and collection process.

publicResponsibility.healthCheckQualifier: The documentation is strong for issues related to technical methodology for geographic aggregation and anonymization. It discusses why the data is beneficial to society. There could be healthier context made available for known privacy issues and the steps taken to ensure all participants understand how their data will be used. The documentation could also state more clearly how the data should and should not be used, with clear remarks about known limitations.

historicContext.healthCheckQualifier: The documentation does not reflect on the ways the data program is at risk for repeating past harms. It does not describe the ways in which U.S. census data collection has considered its relationship and contribution to systemic injustice.

potentialImpact.healthCheckQualifier: There is healthy documentation about potential positive impact and future funding dependent on this data program. There is not very much easily discoverable documentation about potential negative impact, especially if there are existing factors which should be flagged to avoid harm.
